repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Economic Management Reform
            Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            and sustainability is likely. The Government's
            ownership, and commitment to the reform program were key
            factors to its highly satisfactory performance, and, the
            satisfactory performance by the Bank, was reflected in the
            design of the operation, built on lessons from previous
            programs, based on a clearly defined reform agenda,
            emphasizing trade liberalization, and enlargement of the
            domestic revenue base. Lessons suggest the simultaneous
            implementation of indirect tax reform, gradual trade
            liberalization, and rationalization of import procedures,
            protected the budget from a potential decline in revenue,
            which could have endangered fiscal adjustment, at the same
            time as it reduced distortions in the allocation of
            resources, and supported a strong supply response. But the
            combination of prudent fiscal, and monetary policies, the
            favorable external environment, and foreign assistance,
            resulted in strong GDP growth, low inflation, and high
            private investment. Furthermore, the focused nature of the
            operation, which concentrated on a limited number of areas,
            enabled the government to focus on actions considered
            critical to the success of the overall reform process, and
            helped implementation, in light of acute capacity constraints.

Mozambique - Economic Management Reform
            Operation Project

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Economic Management Reform
            Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Management Reform Operation
            Project aims at sustaining growth with poverty reduction and
            diminishing dependency on external aid over the medium to
            long run. The project will be disbursed in two equal
            tranches. The operation, designed to support explicit the
            country assistance strategy and the heavily indebted poor
            countries (HIPC) objectives, is part of a continuing set of
            reforms designed to consolidate a stable macroeconomic
            environment, sustain growth, and reduce poverty through
            improvements in the sustainability of public service
            delivery. However, the operation involves three types of
            risks. First, in spite of progress in building institutional
            and managerial capacity, weaknesses remain which could slow
            down execution or compromise the quality of reforms. Second,
            resistance to further trade liberalization and tax reform
            might be expected. Third, parliamentary and presidential
            elections are planned for 1999, involving some risk of
            slippage in implementing reforms perceived to be unpopular.
            These risks are mitigated by the Government's
            demonstrated commitment to a wide-ranging reform program,
            and by its ongoing efforts to carry out systematic
            consultation with stakeholders.
